div.div: This article was originally published in

div.h1: Getting there from here. Remembering the future of digital humanities: Roberto Busa Award lecture 2013

div.div: King’s College London, UK and University of Western Sydney, Australia
Search for other works by this author on:
Literary and Linguistic Computing, Volume 29, Issue 3, September 2014, Pages 283–306, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqu022

div.p: Willard McCarty, Getting there from here. Remembering the future of digital humanities: Roberto Busa Award lecture 2013, Literary and Linguistic Computing, Volume 29, Issue 3, September 2014, Pages 283–306, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqu022

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: In this slightly modified version of my 2013 Roberto Busa Prize lecture, I look from the first four decades of digital humanities through its present toward a possible future. I find a means to construct this future by paying close attention to the enemy we need in order to grow: the fear that closed down the horizons of imaginative exploration during the years of the Cold War and that re-presents itself now clothed in numerous techno-scientific challenges to the human.
